reasoning: The critique targets an important supporting plank in Section 2.3/2.3.4: that key moral mistakes (digital personhood, space/resource allocation) can be effectively irreversible, so a single early flaw can permanently forfeit most value. If that irreversibility premise were broadly false, the paper’s “fragility”/“narrow target” story would be weakened. However, irreversibility is not the sole basis for the paper’s conclusion: much of the case also comes from (i) many independent dimensions of value (multiplicative/product model), (ii) moral uncertainty and ‘fussiness’ across plausible value functions, and (iii) scale and value-efficiency arguments where even temporary long periods of misallocation can entail large losses. The objection is moderately strong: it plausibly points out that several examples (wellbeing theory, equality norms, banned goods) look corrigible under continued inquiry, and that the paper would need a more explicit “uncorrectable before reflection” mechanism/timing argument. But it remains largely programmatic: it doesn’t show that correction is likely fast enough relative to expansion/lock-in, nor does it engage the paper’s own lock-in-enabling mechanisms (e.g., defense-dominant control of space, institutional/power lock-in, value lock-in via AGI). Relevance is high because correctability vs lock-in is closely tied to Forethought’s active research concerns about persistent path dependence/lock-in and how it interacts with flourishing work.
title: "Correctability Undermines Fragility"
